line_text: Had we but world enough and time,
This coyness, lady, were no crime.
We would sit down, and think which way
To walk, and pass our long love's day.
Thou by the Indian Ganges' side
Shouldst rubies find; I by the tide
Of Humber would complain. I would
Love you ten years before the flood,
We were very tired, we were very merry—
We had gone back and forth all night on the ferry;
And you ate an apple, and I ate a pear,
From a dozen of each we had bought somewhere;
And the sky went wan, and the wind came cold,
And the sun rose dripping, a bucketful of gold.
Should auld acquaintance be forgot,
And never brought to mind?
Should auld acquaintance be forgot,
And auld lang syne!
For auld lang syne, my dear,
For auld lang syne.
We'll tak a cup o' kindness yet,
For auld lang syne.

poem_title: To My Dear and Loving Husband
line_text: If ever two were one, then surely we.

poem_title: To My Dear and Loving Husband
line_text: If ever man were loved by wife, then thee.

poem_title: To My Dear and Loving Husband
line_text: If ever wife was happy in a man,

poem_title: To My Dear and Loving Husband
line_text: Compare with me, ye women, if you can.

poem_title: To My Dear and Loving Husband
line_text: I prize thy love more than whole mines of gold,

poem_title: To My Dear and Loving Husband
line_text: Or all the riches that the East doth hold.
The year is dying in the night;
Ring out, wild bells, and let him die.
Ring out the old, ring in the new,
Ring, happy bells, across the snow:
The year is going, let him go;
Ring out the false, ring in the true.

poem_title: An Essay on Man: Epistle I
line_text: Hope springs eternal in the human breast:

poem_title: An Essay on Man: Epistle I
line_text: Man never is, but always to be blest:

poem_title: An Essay on Man: Epistle I
line_text: The soul, uneasy and confin'd from home,

poem_title: An Essay on Man: Epistle I
line_text: Rests and expatiates in a life to come.

poem_title: An Essay on Man: Epistle I
line_text: Lo! the poor Indian, whose untutor'd mind

poem_title: An Essay on Man: Epistle I
line_text: Sees God in clouds, or hears him in the wind;

poem_title: An Essay on Man: Epistle I
line_text: His soul, proud science never taught to stray

poem_title: An Essay on Man: Epistle I
line_text: Far as the solar walk, or milky way;

poem_title: To the Memory of My Beloved the Author, Mr. William Shakespeare
line_text: I therefore will begin. Soul of the age!

poem_title: To the Memory of My Beloved the Author, Mr. William Shakespeare
line_text: The applause, delight, the wonder of our stage!

poem_title: To the Memory of My Beloved the Author, Mr. William Shakespeare
line_text: My Shakespeare, rise! I will not lodge thee by

poem_title: To the Memory of My Beloved the Author, Mr. William Shakespeare
line_text: Chaucer, or Spenser, or bid Beaumont lie

poem_title: To the Memory of My Beloved the Author, Mr. William Shakespeare
line_text: A little further, to make thee a room:

poem_title: To the Memory of My Beloved the Author, Mr. William Shakespeare
line_text: Thou art a monument without a tomb,

poem_title: To the Memory of My Beloved the Author, Mr. William Shakespeare
line_text: And art alive still while thy book doth live

poem_title: To the Memory of My Beloved the Author, Mr. William Shakespeare
line_text: And we have wits to read and praise to give.
